body.header: Look at this list of possible problems and read any you think applied to you in this task.

ol.li: Practise listening to the radio and repeating the information you hear. Ask yourself what the statements and remarks mean.
When you study, practise reading the instructions out loud (under your breath, if you are embarrassed!), so you are careful to read every word.
Practise describing things (ANYTHING – from a chair, to a computer) either to yourself, to a friend, or to anyone who will listen.
Use who-, which- and what- questions to derive answers which you can compose into a descriptive account
Play games in which you and friends take turns to talk for just one minute on any topic.
Play the same game, but without saying "the", to make it more fun.
Get out your revision and grammar books, and do as many basic grammar exercises as you can stand.
Then do some more!
Pick three grammar exercises you find easy, then do one that you find really difficult.
Write a list of five grammar points that you have particular difficulties with – then revise one a day, for five days.
Read stories in English.
Read newspaper articles in English that are about subjects you find interesting.
Read comics in English.
Watch English language films.
Make vocabulary lists and carry them with you.

Keep a notebook with you and write down the names of things you see – look them up in the dictionary. Look at them again and again. As your list gets longer and longer, keep looking back. It's amazing how fast your vocabulary will increase.
Listen to the radio, watch English language films.
Work out what your personal problem sounds are.
Practice them.
Record yourself speaking, and listen to yourself.
Practice again.
Learn the lists of useful phrases given in different units of this course.
Play a game with a friend – describe an object or idea, without naming it, and see how quickly your friend can guess what it is.
Think of some particularly memorable events in your life – practice describing them to a friend, in just a few sentences.
If you can, use the internet to practice natural, informal English.
